Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Guardian Angel---Enabling Mobile Safety Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
To date, safety services are typically constructed as dedicated stovepipe systems focusing on high reliability and a specific area of risk (e.g., automotive safety systems). Usage of  such services remains limited since they require a dedicated investment for each system. This project trades off the ultra-high reliability of dedicated systems for the much more  rapid adoption of safety services that comes with integrating them directly into mobiles and wearables. By demonstrating the feasibility of this approach, this project can contribute to saving lives, such as some of the more than 30,000 traffic fatalities in the United States each year. It can also inform regulatory policy for safety services  at the CPSC, NHTSA, or FCC. Moreover, the PIs will not only train graduate students to conduct the research but also actively include undergraduates and high school students through research internship programs. Results will be disseminated through scholarly publications, active outreach to the wireless and mobile industry through WINLAB's industry events and connections.

This project seeks to demonstrate that the mobile devices we carry and wear can provide effective safety services. This is particularly relevant where our devices contribute to dangers by causing distractions for drivers and pedestrians. This project therefore pursues the vision of a system that offsets such unsafe use by continually sensing our activities and surroundings, identifying potentially dangerous situations, and mitigating them through appropriate interventions. At a technical level, the primary challenge lies not only in designing precise sensing techniques but in understanding and managing the level of confidence provided by these techniques. A key observation is that there are usually multiple possible interventions of varying levels of intrusiveness and tolerance to false positives. It is therefore important to match interventions to the confidence level provided by the sensors. To address this challenge, the project develops system support and a toolkit to help developers track and manage mobile  sensing uncertainty. It explores crowdsourcing failure and relevance data  from a large user population and automatically estimating the confidence provided  by internal sensing and activity recognition components. The toolkit can further use the obtained metrics to help adapt sensing or application behavior. The system might conserve energy by switching one context sensor to a fallback mode from a diversity mode; or, the system could  switch to a different intervention if the level of confidence has changed. System validation includes prototyping two application use cases, which sense and mitigate mobile device distractions for drivers and pedestrians. Together, these techniques form the system, which supports development of many other effective safety services on mobile devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrates that the mobile devices we carry and wear can play the protective role of a guardian angel and avert dangers ranging from traffic hazards to missteps and falls. We develop the Guardian Angel system that offsets unsafe use by continually sensing our activities and surroundings, identifying potential dangers, and mitigating them through appropriate interventions. The developed Guardian Angel system focuses on the following three specific applications (1) Driver Safety, (2) Pedestrian Safety, and (3) Generalizing Applications: Home Safety and Beyond. 

(1)  Driver Safety. A driver safety application represents the first cornerstone of the Guardian Angel system since this is typically assumed to be the greatest safety risk of mobile device use. We build on the driver-context sensing techniques from our preliminary work to develop an end-to-end safety system and use this to validate and refine our framework, platform, and toolkit ideas. We have focused on two thrusts in this research activity. First, we design an array of driver safety interventions and associated feedback mechanisms to test our hypothesis that the tolerance to false positives depends on the intervention and that such information can be effectively crowdsourced. Second, we develop robust sensing techniques that are less dependent on external devices and demonstrate how they can be matched to external devices. The driver-safety service integrates various mechanisms for determining the driver phone use and has the capability to intelligently choose the appropriate detection mechanism based on the sensor availability. 

 (2)  Pedestrian Safety. Pedestrian safety serves as our second application case study. It presents increased challenges in safety-context sensing but also allows us to experiment with a broader range of interventions. In this research component, we use mobile and wearable devices to help in alerting pedestrians and drivers to potentially hazardous situations. Given the high density of vehicles and pedestrians (on sidewalks) in some downtown areas, triggering warnings simply based on proximity to vehicles would likely lead to warning fatigue and reduced effectiveness of the system. In our developed Guardian Angel system, we first identify sensing modules that can detect hazardous situations and match them to a precisely targeted intervention. The sensing modules include whether a pedestrian is using the phone (i.e., texting, talking or listening to music), when a pedestrian is walking (e.g., at night), and whether it is in a poorly-lit area. Our system also distinguishes safe walking on sidewalks from the unsafe crossing of streets. We identify several priority scenarios and important factors that contribute to pedestrian accident risks based on traffic safety reports (e.g., from the NHTSA). Given this understanding of crash scenarios, we identify key features that could serve as input into a warning system algorithm.

 (3)  Generalizing Applications: Home Safety and Beyond. To generalize the system beyond distraction-related safety issues, we also consider home safety and security monitoring for both the young and the elderly.  By using existing wireless signals at home, we develop a system that senses the wireless signals emitted from WiFi devices throughout the home to detect significant deviations from routines and automatically notifies close family or caregivers, if necessary. This approach does not need dedicated sensors or additional infrastructure. People’s activities affect the signal propagation pattern, which results in different received radio signal patterns for different activities. The received signal patterns is used to classify regular activities of people, and such classifiers are used for home safety monitoring. Such a system can be also used for security monitoring: if human activities are detected during the times a home should be empty, an intrusion alert can be sent.

This project leads to increased availability and better effectiveness of safety services. The project includes close collaboration with industry partners interested in this space (e.g., AT&T and Honda), which increases the chance for technology transfer. Major research results have been disseminated to academia and industry through paper presentations and publications in conferences and journals (e.g., MobiCom, MobiSys, SenSys, UbiComp, CHI, and TMC). The project has enabled three graduate students (one each from Rutgers, Stevens, and Florida State) to collaborate with each other and to gain experience with the challenges of building the Gradian Angel system. The research results have been integrated into the graduate level course "CIS5900 Wireless and Mobile Computing". Moreover, we dismiss and discuss our research findings in the departmental event "CS EXPO" and departmental seminar, where we invite researchers from both academia and industry to give talks about cutting-edge research topics each year. These events enable us to present research findings to students, faculty, and experts from industry.
